member.name: M:net.openstack.Core.Caching.ICache`1.Get(System.String,System.Func{`0},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets a value cached for a particular key, updating the value if necessary.
member.remarks:
This method returns a previously cached value when possible. If any of the following conditions are met, the function will be called to obtain a new value for which is then added to the cache, replacing any previously cached value.
The cache does not contain any value associated with .
is true.
The previously cached value for is no longer valid. The exact algorithm for determining whether or not a value is valid in implementation-defined.
If any of the above conditions is met and is null, the previously cached value for , if any, is removed from the cache and the default value for is returned.
member.param: The key.
A function which returns a new value for the specified , or null if no update function available (see remarks).
If true, the value associated with will be always be refreshed by calling , even if a value is already cached.
member.returns: The cached value associated with the specified . If no cached value is available (see remarks), the method returns the default value for .
member.exception: If is null.

member.name: F:net.openstack.Core.BackoffPolicy._default
member.summary: This is the backing field for the property.

member.name: M:net.openstack.Core.BackoffPolicy.GetBackoffIntervals
member.remarks:
The default implementation uses the following progressive back-off strategy.
No delay before polling the first time.
Poll once per second, up to 10 times.
Poll once per 5 seconds, up to 10 times.
Poll once per 15 seconds, up to 10 times.
Poll once per 30 seconds indefinitely.

member.name: T:net.openstack.Core.Domain.Converters.NamespaceDoc
member.summary: The namespace defines specialized JSON converters for calling the OpenStack REST APIs. These converters are useful for standard .NET classes that have a one or more specific representations in the OpenStack APIs (e.g. or ), and for extensible enumerations (e.g. ).

member.name: T:net.openstack.Core.Domain.Converters.PhysicalAddressSimpleConverter
member.summary: This implementation of allows for JSON serialization and deserialization of objects using a simple string representation. Serialization produces an IEEE 802 representation of the form 00:11:22:33:44:55, and deserialization supports representations using hyphens or colons, along with bare strings containing 12 hexadecimal digits.

member.name: M:net.openstack.Core.Domain.Converters.PhysicalAddressSimpleConverter.ConvertToObject(System.String)
member.remarks:
If is an empty string, this method returns null. Otherwise, this method converts IEEE 802 addresses containing hyphens or colons to a bare representation, and then uses for deserialization. As a result, this converter can handle physical addresses in any of the following forms:
01-23-45-67-89-ab
01:23:45:67:89:ab
0123456789ab

member.name: T:net.openstack.Core.Domain.Converters.IPAddressSimpleConverter
member.summary: This implementation of allows for JSON serialization and deserialization of objects using a simple string representation. Serialization is performed using , and deserialization is performed using .
member.seealso: List Addresses (OpenStack Compute API v2 and Extensions Reference)
List Addresses by Network (OpenStack Compute API v2 and Extensions Reference)

member.name: M:net.openstack.Core.Domain.Converters.IPAddressSimpleConverter.ConvertToObject(System.String)
member.remarks: If is an empty string, this method returns null. Otherwise, this method uses for deserialization.

member.name: T:net.openstack.Core.Domain.DiskConfiguration
member.summary: This enumeration is part of the disk configuration extension, which adds at attribute to images and servers to control how the disk is partitioned when servers are created, rebuilt, or resized.
member.remarks: This class functions as a strongly-typed enumeration of known disk configurations, with added support for unknown types returned by a server extension.
member.seealso: Disk Configuration Extension (Rackspace Next Generation Cloud Servers Developer Guide - API v2)

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with the specified name.

member.summary: Gets the instance with the specified name.
member.param: The name.
member.exception: If is null.
If is empty.

member.name: P:net.openstack.Core.Domain.DiskConfiguration.Auto
member.summary: Gets a representing automatic configuration.
member.remarks: The server is built with a single partition the size of the target flavor disk. The file system is automatically adjusted to fit the entire partition. This keeps things simple and automated. is valid only for images and servers with a single partition that use the EXT3 file system. This is the default setting for applicable Rackspace base images.

member.name: P:net.openstack.Core.Domain.DiskConfiguration.Manual
member.summary: Gets a manual configuration.
member.remarks: The server is built using whatever partition scheme and file system is in the source image. If the target flavor disk is larger, the remaining disk space is left unpartitioned. This enables images to have non-EXT3 file systems, multiple partitions, and so on, and enables you to manage the disk configuration.

member.name: T:net.openstack.Core.Domain.DiskConfiguration.Converter
member.summary: Provides support for serializing and deserializing objects to JSON string values.

This class functions as a strongly-typed enumeration of known power states, with added support for unknown states returned by a server extension.
This property is defined by the Rackspace-specific Extended Status Extension to the OpenStack Compute API. The API does not regulate the status values, so it is possible that values can be added, removed, or renamed.

member.name: T:net.openstack.Core.Domain.ResourceHints
member.summary: This class models the Resource Hints of the home document described by Home Documents for HTTP APIs.
member.remarks:
Resource hints allow clients to find relevant information about interacting with a resource beforehand, as a means of optimizing communications, as well as advertising available behaviors (e.g., to aid in laying out a user interface for consuming the API).
Hints are just that - they are not a "contract", and are to only be taken as advisory. The runtime behavior of the resource always overrides hinted information.
For example, a resource might hint that the PUT method is allowed on all "widget" resources. This means that generally, the user has the ability to PUT to a particular resource, but a specific resource could reject a PUT based upon access control or other considerations. More fine-grained information might be gathered by interacting with the resource (e.g., via a GET), or by another resource "containing" it (such as a "widgets" collection).
The current specification defines a set of common hints, based upon information that's discoverable by directly interacting with resources. A future draft will explain how to define new hints.
member.seealso: Resource Hints (Home Documents for HTTP APIs - draft-nottingham-json-home-03)

member.name: M:net.openstack.Core.Domain.ServerBase.Resize(System.String,System.String,net.openstack.Core.Domain.DiskConfiguration)
member.summary: Initiates an asynchronous resize of the server. A server resize is performed by specifying a new for the server.
member.remarks: Following a resize operation, the original server is not immediately removed. After testing if the resulting server is operating successfully, a call should be made to to keep the resized server, or to to revert to the original server. If 24 hours pass and neither of these methods is called, the server will be automatically confirmed.
member.param: The new name for the resized server.
The new flavor. This is obtained from Flavor.Id.
The disk configuration. If the value is null, the default configuration for the specified image is used.
member.returns: true if the resize operation is successfully started; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:net.openstack.Core.Domain.ServerBase.ConfirmResize
member.summary: Confirms a completed asynchronous server resize action.

member.returns: true if the resize operation was confirmed; otherwise, false.
member.exception: If the REST API request failed.

member.name: M:net.openstack.Core.Domain.ServerBase.RevertResize
member.summary: Cancels and reverts a server resize action.

member.exception: If the REST API request failed.

member.name: M:net.openstack.Core.Domain.ServerBase.Rescue
member.summary: Places the server in rescue mode.
member.remarks:
This operation is completed asynchronously. To wait for the server to enter rescue mode, call with the state .
The provider may limit the duration of rescue mode, after which the rescue image is destroyed and the server attempts to reboot. Rescue mode may be explicitly exited at any time by calling .
member.returns: The root password assigned for use during rescue mode.
member.exception: If the REST API request failed.

member.name: M:net.openstack.Core.Domain.ServerBase.UnRescue
member.summary: Takes the server out of rescue mode.
member.remarks:
This operation is completed asynchronously. To wait for the server to exit rescue mode, call .
The provider may limit the duration of rescue mode, after which the rescue image is destroyed and the server attempts to reboot. Rescue mode may be explicitly exited at any time by calling .
member.returns: true if the server exited rescue mode; otherwise, false.
member.exception: If the REST API request failed.

member.name: M:net.openstack.Core.Domain.SimpleServerImage.WaitForActive(System.Int32,System.Nullable{System.TimeSpan},System.Action{System.Int32})
member.summary: Waits for the image to enter the state.
member.remarks:
When the method returns, the current instance is updated to reflect the state of the image at the end of the operation.
This is a blocking operation and will not return until the image enters either the state, an error state, or the retry count is exceeded.
member.param: Number of times to poll the image's status.
The time to wait between polling requests for the image status. If this value is null, the default is 2.4 seconds.
A callback delegate to execute each time the value increases. If this value is null, progress updates are not reported.
member.exception:
If is less than 0.
-or-
If is negative.
If the REST API request failed.

member.summary: Represents the task status of a server.

This class functions as a strongly-typed enumeration of known task states, with added support for unknown states returned by a server extension.
This property is defined by the Rackspace-specific Extended Status Extension to the OpenStack Compute API. The API does not regulate the status values, so it is possible that values can be added, removed, or renamed.

member.name: T:net.openstack.Core.Domain.CloudNetwork
member.summary: Represents the detailed information for a labeled network in Rackspace Cloud Networks.
member.seealso: Overview (Rackspace Cloud Networks Developer Guide - OpenStack Networking API v2)

member.name: P:net.openstack.Core.Domain.CloudNetwork.Id
member.summary: Gets the network ID.

member.name: P:net.openstack.Core.Domain.CloudNetwork.Cidr
member.summary: Gets the CIDR for the network.

member.name: P:net.openstack.Core.Domain.CloudNetwork.Label
member.summary: Gets the name of the network.
member.remarks:
The Rackspace Cloud Networks product predefines two networks:
PublicNet provides access to the Internet, Rackspace services such as Cloud Monitoring, Managed Cloud Support, RackConnect, Cloud Backup, and certain operating system updates. When you list networks through Cloud Networks, PublicNet is labeled public.
ServiceNet Provides access to Rackspace services such as Cloud Files, Cloud Databases, and Cloud Backup, and to certain packages and patches through an internal only, multi-tenant network connection within each Rackspace data center. When you list networks through Cloud Networks, ServiceNet is labeled as private.
member.seealso: Overview (Rackspace Cloud Networks Developer Guide - OpenStack Networking API v2)

member.name: M:net.openstack.Core.Providers.IQueueingService.ClaimMessageAsync(net.openstack.Core.Domain.Queues.QueueName,System.Nullable{System.Int32},System.TimeSpan,System.TimeSpan,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Claim messages from a queue.
member.remarks:
When the claim is no longer required, the code should call or to ensure the following actions are taken.
Messages which are part of this claim which were not processed are made available to other nodes.
The claim resource is cleaned up without waiting for the time-to-live to expire.
Messages which are not deleted before the claim is released will be eligible for reclaiming by another process.
member.param: The queue name.
The maximum number of messages to claim. If this value is null, a provider-specific default value is used.
The time to wait before the server automatically releases the claim.
The time to wait, after the time-to-live for the claim expires, before the server allows the claimed messages to be deleted due to the individual message's time-to-live expiring.
The that the task will observe.
member.returns: A object representing the asynchronous operation. When the task completes successfully, the property will contain object representing the claim.
member.exception: If is null.

If is less than or equal to 0.
-or-
If is negative or .
-or-
If is negative.
If the REST request does not return successfully.
member.seealso: Claim Messages (OpenStack Marconi API v1 Blueprint)

member.summary: Clones a domain registered in the DNS service, optionally cloning its subdomains as well.

true to recursively clone subdomains; otherwise, false to only clone the top-level domain and its records. Cloned subdomain configurations are modified the same way that cloned top-level domain configurations are modified. If this is null, a provider-specific default value is used.
true to replace occurrences of the reference domain name with the new domain name in comments on the cloned (new) domain. If this is null, a provider-specific default value is used.
true to replace occurrences of the reference domain name with the new domain name in email addresses on the cloned (new) domain. If this is null, a provider-specific default value is used.

true to replace occurrences of the reference domain name with the new domain name in data fields (of records) on the cloned (new) domain. Does not affect NS records. If this is null, a provider-specific default value is used.

member.name: M:net.openstack.Core.Synchronous.LoadBalancerServiceExtensions.SetSessionPersistence(net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.ILoadBalancerService,net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.Objects.LoadBalancers.LoadBalancerId,net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.Objects.LoadBalancers.SessionPersistence)
member.summary: Sets the session persistence configuration for a load balancer.
member.remarks:
You can only set one of the session persistence modes on a load balancer, and it can only support one protocol, so if you set mode for an HTTP load balancer, then it will support session persistence for HTTP requests only. Likewise, if you set mode for an HTTPS load balancer, then it will support session persistence for HTTPS requests only.
If you want to support session persistence for both HTTP and HTTPS requests concurrently, then you have 2 choices:
Use two load balancers, one configured for session persistence for HTTP requests and the other configured for session persistence for HTTPS requests. That way, the load balancers together will support session persistence for both HTTP and HTTPS requests concurrently, with each load balancer supporting one of the protocols.
Use one load balancer, configure it for session persistence for HTTP requests, and then enable SSL termination for that load balancer (refer to Section 4.17, "SSL Termination" for details). The load balancer will then support session persistence for both HTTP and HTTPS requests concurrently.
member.param: The load balancer service instance.
The load balancer ID. This is obtained from LoadBalancer.Id.
The session persistence configuration.
member.exception: If is null.

If is null.
-or-
If is null.
If the REST request does not return successfully.
member.seealso: Manage Session Persistence (Rackspace Cloud Load Balancers Developer Guide - API v1.0)

member.name: M:net.openstack.Core.Synchronous.LoadBalancerServiceExtensions.GetContentCaching(net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.ILoadBalancerService,net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.Objects.LoadBalancers.LoadBalancerId)
member.summary: Gets whether or not content caching is enabled for a load balancer.
member.remarks:
When content caching is enabled, recently-accessed files are stored on the load balancer for easy retrieval by web clients. Content caching improves the performance of high traffic web sites by temporarily storing data that was recently accessed. While it's cached, requests for that data will be served by the load balancer, which in turn reduces load off the back end nodes. The result is improved response times for those requests and less load on the web server.
For more information about content caching, refer to the following Knowledge Center article: Content Caching for Cloud Load Balancers.
member.param: The load balancer service instance.
The load balancer ID. This is obtained from LoadBalancer.Id.
member.returns: true if content caching is enabled for the load balancer; otherwise, false.
member.exception: If is null.
If is null.
If the REST request does not return successfully.
member.seealso: Content Caching (Rackspace Cloud Load Balancers Developer Guide - API v1.0)

member.summary: Enables or disables content caching for a load balancer.
member.remarks:
When content caching is enabled, recently-accessed files are stored on the load balancer for easy retrieval by web clients. Content caching improves the performance of high traffic web sites by temporarily storing data that was recently accessed. While it's cached, requests for that data will be served by the load balancer, which in turn reduces load off the back end nodes. The result is improved response times for those requests and less load on the web server.
For more information about content caching, refer to the following Knowledge Center article: Content Caching for Cloud Load Balancers.
member.param: The load balancer service instance.

true to enable content caching on the load balancer; otherwise, false.

member.name: T:net.openstack.Core.Synchronous.NamespaceDoc
member.summary:
The namespace defines classes providing extension methods for calling asynchronous services in a synchronous manner.
These extension methods are not recommended for use in new development, but are provided as a compatibility aid for projects where external restrictions preclude the direct use of the asynchronous APIs.

member.summary: Claim messages from a queue.
member.remarks:
When the claim is no longer required, the code should call or to ensure the following actions are taken.
Messages which are part of this claim which were not processed are made available to other nodes.
The claim resource is cleaned up without waiting for the time-to-live to expire.
Messages which are not deleted before the claim is released will be eligible for reclaiming by another process.
member.param: The queueing service instance.
The queue name.
The maximum number of messages to claim. If this value is null, a provider-specific default value is used.
The time to wait before the server automatically releases the claim.
The time to wait, after the time-to-live for the claim expires, before the server allows the claimed messages to be deleted due to the individual message's time-to-live expiring.
member.returns: A object representing the claim.
member.exception: If is null.
If is null.

If is less than or equal to 0.
-or-
If is negative or .
-or-
If is negative.

This method attempts to filter the remaining items to those matching . If is null, the user's default region is used. If no services match the specified region, this argument is ignored.

true to replace occurrences of the reference domain name with the new domain name in comments on the cloned (new) domain. If this is null, a provider-specific default value is used.
true to replace occurrences of the reference domain name with the new domain name in email addresses on the cloned (new) domain. If this is null, a provider-specific default value is used.

true to replace occurrences of the reference domain name with the new domain name in data fields (of records) on the cloned (new) domain. Does not affect NS records. If this is null, a provider-specific default value is used.

member.summary: Sets the session persistence configuration for a load balancer.
member.remarks:
You can only set one of the session persistence modes on a load balancer, and it can only support one protocol, so if you set mode for an HTTP load balancer, then it will support session persistence for HTTP requests only. Likewise, if you set mode for an HTTPS load balancer, then it will support session persistence for HTTPS requests only.
If you want to support session persistence for both HTTP and HTTPS requests concurrently, then you have 2 choices:
Use two load balancers, one configured for session persistence for HTTP requests and the other configured for session persistence for HTTPS requests. That way, the load balancers together will support session persistence for both HTTP and HTTPS requests concurrently, with each load balancer supporting one of the protocols.
Use one load balancer, configure it for session persistence for HTTP requests, and then enable SSL termination for that load balancer (refer to Section 4.17, "SSL Termination" for details). The load balancer will then support session persistence for both HTTP and HTTPS requests concurrently.
member.param: The load balancer ID. This is obtained from LoadBalancer.Id.
The session persistence configuration.
Specifies when the representing the asynchronous server operation should be considered complete.
The that the task will observe.
An optional callback object to receive progress notifications, if is . If this is null, no progress notifications are sent.
member.returns: A object representing the asynchronous operation. If is , the task will not be considered complete until the load balancer transitions out of the state.
member.exception:
If is null.

member.name: M:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.ILoadBalancerService.GetContentCachingAsync(net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.Objects.LoadBalancers.LoadBalancerId,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Gets whether or not content caching is enabled for a load balancer.
member.remarks:
When content caching is enabled, recently-accessed files are stored on the load balancer for easy retrieval by web clients. Content caching improves the performance of high traffic web sites by temporarily storing data that was recently accessed. While it's cached, requests for that data will be served by the load balancer, which in turn reduces load off the back end nodes. The result is improved response times for those requests and less load on the web server.
For more information about content caching, refer to the following Knowledge Center article: Content Caching for Cloud Load Balancers.
member.param: The load balancer ID. This is obtained from LoadBalancer.Id.
The that the task will observe.
member.returns: A object representing the asynchronous operation. When the operation completes, the property will be true if content caching is enabled for the load balancer; otherwise, false.
member.exception: If is null.
If the REST request does not return successfully.
member.seealso: Content Caching (Rackspace Cloud Load Balancers Developer Guide - API v1.0)

member.summary: Enables or disables content caching for a load balancer.

The result is improved response times for those requests and less load on the web server.
For more information about content caching, refer to the following Knowledge Center article: Content Caching for Cloud Load Balancers.

member.name: M:net.openstack.Core.Providers.IBlockStorageProvider.CreateSnapshot(System.String,System.Boolean,System.String,System.String,System.String,net.openstack.Core.Domain.CloudIdentity)
member.summary: Creates a new snapshot.
member.remarks:
The snapshot operation is performed asynchronously. After this call returns, may be called to wait until the snapshot process is complete and the snapshot is available.
Creating a snapshot makes a point-in-time copy of the volume. All writes to the volume should be flushed before creating the snapshot, either by un-mounting any file systems on the volume, or by detaching the volume before creating the snapshot. Snapshots are incremental, so each time you create a new snapshot, you are appending the incremental changes for the new snapshot to the previous one. The previous snapshot is still available. Note that you can create a new volume from the snapshot if desired.
member.param: The ID of the volume to snapshot. The value should be obtained from Volume.Id.
If true, the snapshot is created even if the volume is currently attached.
Name of the snapshot.
Description of snapshot.
The region in which to execute this action. If not specified, the user's default region will be used.
The cloud identity to use for this request. If not specified, the default identity for the current provider instance will be used.
member.returns: A object containing the details about the snapshot.
member.exception: If is null.
If is empty.

If the provider does not support the given type.
-or-
The specified is not supported.

If is null and no default identity is available for the provider.
-or-
If is null and no default region is available for the provider.
If the REST API request failed.
member.seealso: Create Snapshot (OpenStack Block Storage Service API Reference)

member.name: P:net.openstack.Core.Domain.Link.Rel
member.summary: Gets the link relation.

list.item: A self link contains a versioned link to the resource. Use these links when the link will be followed immediately.
A bookmark link provides a permanent link to a resource that is appropriate for long-term storage.
An alternate link can contain an alternative representation of the resource. For example, an OpenStack Compute image might have an alternate representation in the OpenStack Image service.

member.seealso: Links and References (OpenStack Compute API v2 and Extensions Reference)

member.name: T:net.openstack.Core.Domain.Personality
member.summary: Describes a file to inject into the file system while creating or rebuilding a server.
member.remarks: You can customize the personality of a server instance by injecting data into its file system. For example, you might want to insert SSH keys, set configuration files, or store data that you want to retrieve from inside the instance. This feature provides a minimal amount of launch-time personalization. If you require significant customization, create a custom image.
member.seealso: Server Personality (OpenStack Compute API V2 and Extensions Reference)

member.name: P:net.openstack.Core.Domain.Personality.Path
member.summary: The path of the file to create on the target file system.
member.remarks: The behavior of the related methods is undefined if the UTF-8 encoded value is longer than 255 bytes.

member.name: P:net.openstack.Core.Domain.Personality.Content
member.summary: The contents of the file to create on the target file system.
member.remarks:
The maximum size of the file contents is determined by the compute provider and may vary based on the image that is used to create the server. The provider may provide a maxPersonalitySize absolute limit, which is a byte limit that is guaranteed to apply to all images in the deployment. Providers can set additional per-image personality limits.
The behavior of the related methods is undefined if the value is not a UTF-8 encoded text file.

member.name: T:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudBlockStorageProvider
member.summary: Provides an implementation of for operating with Rackspace's Cloud Block Storage product.

remarks.para: The Cloud Block Storage Provider enables simple access to the Rackspace Cloud Block Storage Volumes as well as Cloud Block Storage Volume Snapshot services. Rackspace Cloud Block Storage is a block level storage solution that allows customers to mount drives or volumes to their Rackspace Next Generation Cloud Servers. The two primary use cases are (1) to allow customers to scale their storage independently from their compute resources, and (2) to allow customers to utilize high performance storage to serve database or I/O-intensive applications.
Highlights of Rackspace Cloud Block Storage include:

list.item: Mount a drive to a Cloud Server to scale storage without paying for more compute capability.
A high performance option for databases and high performance applications, leveraging solid state drives for speed.
A standard speed option for customers who just need additional storage on their Cloud Server.
Cloud Block Storage is an add-on feature to Next Generation Cloud Servers. Customers may not attach Cloud Block Storage volumes to other instances, like first generation Cloud Servers.
Cloud Block Storage is multi-tenant rather than dedicated.
When volumes are destroyed, Rackspace keeps that disk space unavailable until zeros have been written to the space to ensure that data is not accessible by any other customers.
Cloud Block Storage allows you to create snapshots that you can save, list, and restore.

member.seealso: OpenStack Block Storage Service API v2 Reference
Rackspace Cloud Block Storage Developer Guide - API v1.0

member.name: M:net.openstack.Core.Providers.IObjectStorageProvider.EnableCDNOnContainer(System.String,System.Int64,System.String,net.openstack.Core.Domain.CloudIdentity)

overloads.summary: When you CDN-enable a container, all the objects within it become available through the Content Delivery Network (CDN). Similarly, once a container is CDN-enabled, any objects added to it in the storage service become CDN-enabled.

remarks.note: This feature is a Rackspace-specific extension to the OpenStack Object Storage Service.

overloads.seealso: CDN-Enable a Container (Rackspace Cloud Files Developer Guide - API v1)

member.summary: Enables CDN on the container using the specified TTL and without log retention.
member.remarks:
If the specified container is already CDN-enabled, this method updates the TTL for the container based on the argument.
This method is a Rackspace-specific extension to the OpenStack Object Storage Service.
The resulting Dictionary<string, string> should use the equality comparer to ensure lookups are not case sensitive.
member.param: The container name.
The time (in seconds) to cache objects in the CDN. Each time the object is accessed after the TTL expires, the CDN re-fetches and caches the object for the TTL period.
The region in which to execute this action. If not specified, the user's default region will be used.
The cloud identity to use for this request. If not specified, the default identity for the current provider instance will be used.

member.summary: Deletes an object from a container.
member.remarks: To support large files, the object storage services allows for a single logical file to be split into multiple segments. The parameter provides a way to delete a segmented file as though it were stored as a single object by deleting both the logical file's metadata and the individual segments. The parameter is ignored if the specified object is not a segmented file.
member.param: The container name.
The object name. Example image_name.jpeg
A collection of custom HTTP headers to include with the request.
Indicates whether the file's segments should be deleted if any exist.

member.name: M:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.Objects.LoadBalancers.LoadBalancerConfiguration`1.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.remarks: This constructor is used during JSON deserialization of derived types.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with the specified values.
member.param: The name of the load balancer.
The load balancing protocol to use for this load balancer.
A collection of objects describing the virtual addresses to assign to the load balancer.
A collection of objects describing the nodes in the load balancer. If this value is null, the load balancer will be created without any nodes.

true to enable half-closed support for the load balancer; otherwise, false. Half-Closed support provides the ability for one end of the connection to terminate its output, while still receiving data from the other end. Only applies to TCP/TCP_CLIENT_FIRST protocols.
A collection of objects describing the access list for the load balancer. If this value is null, the load balancer will be created without an access list configured.
The load balancing algorithm that defines how traffic should be directed between back-end nodes. If this value is null, a provider-specific default algorithm will be used.
true to enable connection logging; otherwise, false. If this value is null, a provider-specific default value will be used.
true to enable content caching; otherwise, false. If this value is null, a provider-specific default value will be used.
A object defining the connection throttling configuration for the load balancer. If this value is null, a provider-specific default value will be used.
A object defining the health monitor to configure for the load balancer. If this value is null, the load balancer will be created with no health monitor configured.
A collection of objects defining the initial metadata for the load balancer. If this value is null, the load balancer will be created without any initial custom metadata.
The timeout value for the load balancer and communications with its nodes. If this value is null, a provider-specific default value will be used.
A object defining the session persistence configuration for the load balancer. If this value is null, the load balancer will be created with session persistence disabled.

member.summary: This class represents the configuration for a new load balancer.

member.name: M:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.Objects.LoadBalancers.LoadBalancerConfiguration.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.remarks: This constructor is used during JSON deserialization of derived types.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with the specified values.
member.param: The name of the load balancer.
The load balancing protocol to use for this load balancer.
A collection of objects describing the virtual addresses to assign to the load balancer.
A collection of objects describing the nodes in the load balancer. If this value is null, the load balancer will be created without any nodes.

true to enable half-closed support for the load balancer; otherwise, false. Half-Closed support provides the ability for one end of the connection to terminate its output, while still receiving data from the other end. Only applies to TCP/TCP_CLIENT_FIRST protocols.
A collection of objects describing the access list for the load balancer. If this value is null, the load balancer will be created without an access list configured.
The load balancing algorithm that defines how traffic should be directed between back-end nodes. If this value is null, a provider-specific default algorithm will be used.
true to enable connection logging; otherwise, false. If this value is null, a provider-specific default value will be used.
true to enable content caching; otherwise, false. If this value is null, a provider-specific default value will be used.
A object defining the connection throttling configuration for the load balancer. If this value is null, a provider-specific default value will be used.
A object defining the health monitor to configure for the load balancer. If this value is null, the load balancer will be created with no health monitor configured.
A collection of objects defining the initial metadata for the load balancer. If this value is null, the load balancer will be created without any initial custom metadata.
The timeout value for the load balancer and communications with its nodes. If this value is null, a provider-specific default value will be used.
A object defining the session persistence configuration for the load balancer. If this value is null, the load balancer will be created with session persistence disabled.

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.AuthToken
member.summary: The X-Auth-Token header, which specifies the token to use for authenticated requests.
member.seealso: Authentication (OpenStack Object Storage API v1 Reference)
Authentication (Rackspace Cloud Files Developer Guide - API v1)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.CdnManagementUrl
member.summary: The X-Cdn-Management-Url header. The value of this header is not defined. Do not use.

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.StorageUrl
member.summary: The X-Storage-Url header, which specifies the base URI for all object storage requests.
member.seealso: Authentication (OpenStack Object Storage API v1 Reference)
Authentication (Rackspace Cloud Files Developer Guide - API v1)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.AccountMetaDataPrefix
member.summary: The X-Account-Meta- header prefix, which specifies the HTTP header prefix for metadata keys associated with an account.
member.seealso: Create or Update Account Metadata (OpenStack Object Storage API v1 Reference)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.AccountBytesUsed
member.summary: The X-Account-Bytes-Used header, which specifies total storage used by an account in bytes. The value of this property is not defined by OpenStack, and may not be consistent across vendors.
member.seealso: Get Account Metadata (OpenStack Object Storage API v1 Reference)
View Account Details (Rackspace Cloud Files Developer Guide - API v1)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.AccountContainerCount
member.summary: The X-Account-Container-Count header, which specifies the number of containers associated with an account. The value of this property is not defined by OpenStack, and may not be consistent across vendors.
member.seealso: Get Account Metadata (OpenStack Object Storage API v1 Reference)
View Account Details (Rackspace Cloud Files Developer Guide - API v1)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.AccountObjectCount
member.summary: The X-Account-Object-Count header, which specifies the number of objects associated with an account. The value of this property is not defined by OpenStack, and may not be consistent across vendors.
member.seealso: Listing and Creating Containers (OpenStack Object Storage API v1 Reference)
View Account Details (Rackspace Cloud Files Developer Guide - API v1)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.ContainerMetaDataPrefix
member.summary: The X-Container-Meta- header prefix, which specifies the HTTP header prefix for metadata keys associated with a container.
member.seealso: Create or Update Container Metadata (OpenStack Object Storage API v1 Reference)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.ContainerRemoveMetaDataPrefix
member.summary: The X-Remove-Container-Meta- header prefix, which specifies the HTTP header prefix for removing metadata keys from a container.
member.remarks: This value is not required in the .NET SDK, since a shorter way to remove metadata is to simply assign an empty string as the value for a metadata key.
member.seealso: Delete Container Metadata (OpenStack Object Storage API v1 Reference)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.ContainerBytesUsed
member.summary: The X-Container-Bytes-Used header, which specifies the total size of all objects stored in a container.
member.seealso: Get Container Metadata (OpenStack Object Storage API v1 Reference)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.ContainerObjectCount
member.summary: The X-Container-Object-Count header, which specifies the total number of objects stored in a container.
member.seealso: Get Container Metadata (OpenStack Object Storage API v1 Reference)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.WebIndex
member.summary: The Web-Index metadata key, which specifies the index page for every pseudo-directory in a website.
member.remarks: If your pseudo-directory does not have a file with the same name as your index file, visits to the sub-directory return a 404 error.
member.seealso: Create Static Website (OpenStack Object Storage API v1 Reference - API v1)
Create Static Website (Rackspace Cloud Files Developer Guide - API v1)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.WebError
member.summary: The Web-Error metadata key, which specifies the suffix for error pages displayed for a website.
member.remarks:
You may create and set custom error pages for visitors to your website; currently, only 401 (Unauthorized) and 404 (Not Found) errors are supported. To do this, set the metadata value .
Error pages are served with the <status> code prepended to the name of the error page you set. For instance, if you set to error.html, 401 errors will display the page 401error.html. Similarly, 404 errors will display 404error.html. You must have both of these pages created in your container when you set the metadata, or your site will display generic error pages.
You need only set the metadata once for your entire static website.
member.seealso: Set Error Pages for Static Website (OpenStack Object Storage API v1 Reference - API v1)
Set Error Pages for Static Website (Rackspace Cloud Files Developer Guide - API v1)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.WebListings
member.summary: The Web-Listings metadata key, which specifies whether or not pseudo-directories should display a list of files instead of returning a 404 error when the pseudo-directory does not contain an index file.
member.remarks: To display a list of files in pseudo-directories instead of an index, set the metadata value to "TRUE" for a container.
member.seealso: Create Static Website (OpenStack Object Storage API v1 Reference - API v1)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.WebListingsCSS
member.summary: The Web-Listings-CSS metadata key, which specifies the stylesheet to use for file listings when is true and a pseudo-directory does not contain an index file.
member.seealso: Create Static Website (OpenStack Object Storage API v1 Reference - API v1)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.VersionsLocation
member.summary: The X-Versions-Location header, which specifies the name of the container where previous versions of objects are stored for a container.
member.seealso: Object Versioning (OpenStack Object Storage API v1 Reference - API v1)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.CdnUri
member.summary: The X-Cdn-Uri header, which specifies the publicly-available URL for a CDN-enabled container.

remarks.note: This header is a Rackspace-specific extension to the OpenStack Object Storage Service.

member.seealso: CDN Container Services (Rackspace Cloud Files Developer Guide - API v1)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.CdnSslUri
member.summary: The X-Cdn-Ssl-Uri header, which specifies the publicly-available URL for SSL access to a CDN-enabled container.

remarks.note: This header is a Rackspace-specific extension to the OpenStack Object Storage Service.

member.seealso: CDN Container Services (Rackspace Cloud Files Developer Guide - API v1)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.CdnStreamingUri
member.summary: The X-Cdn-Streaming-Uri header, which specifies the publicly-available URL for streaming access to a CDN-enabled container.

remarks.note: This header is a Rackspace-specific extension to the OpenStack Object Storage Service.

member.seealso: CDN Container Services (Rackspace Cloud Files Developer Guide - API v1)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.CdnTTL
member.summary: The X-Ttl header, which specifies the Time To Live (TTL) in seconds for a CDN-enabled container.

remarks.note: This header is a Rackspace-specific extension to the OpenStack Object Storage Service.

member.seealso: CDN-Enable a Container (Rackspace Cloud Files Developer Guide - API v1)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.CdnLogRetention
member.summary: The X-Log-Retention header, which specifies whether or not log retention is enabled for a CDN-enabled container.

remarks.note: This header is a Rackspace-specific extension to the OpenStack Object Storage Service.

member.seealso: List a CDN-Enabled Container's Metadata (Rackspace Cloud Files Developer Guide - API v1)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.CdnEnabled
member.summary: The X-Cdn-Enabled header, which specifies whether or not a container is CDN-enabled.

remarks.note: This header is a Rackspace-specific extension to the OpenStack Object Storage Service.

member.seealso: CDN-Enable a Container (Rackspace Cloud Files Developer Guide - API v1)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.CdnIosUri
member.summary: The X-Cdn-Ios-Uri header, which specifies the publicly-available URL for iOS streaming access to a CDN-enabled container.

remarks.note: This header is a Rackspace-specific extension to the OpenStack Object Storage Service.

member.seealso: iOS Streaming (Rackspace Cloud Files Developer Guide - API v1)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.ObjectMetaDataPrefix
member.summary: The X-Object-Meta- header prefix, which specifies the HTTP header prefix for metadata keys associated with an object.
member.seealso: Update Object Metadata (OpenStack Object Storage API v1 Reference)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.ObjectDeleteAfter
member.summary: The X-Delete-After header, which specifies the relative time (in seconds from "now") after which an object should expire, not be served, and be deleted completely from the storage system.
member.seealso: Expiring Objects with the X-Delete-After and X-Delete-At Headers (OpenStack Object Storage API v1 Reference)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.ObjectDeleteAt
member.summary: The X-Delete-At header, which specifies the absolute time (in Unix Epoch format) after which an object should expire, not be served, and be deleted completely from the storage system.
member.remarks: Unix time is specified as the number of seconds elapsed since 00:00:00 UTC, 1 January 1970, not counting leap seconds.
member.seealso: Unix time (Wikipedia)
Expiring Objects with the X-Delete-After and X-Delete-At Headers (OpenStack Object Storage API v1 Reference)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.Etag
member.summary: The ETag header, which specifies the MD5 checksum of the data in an object stored in Object Storage.
member.seealso: Create or Update Object (OpenStack Object Storage API v1 Reference)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.Destination
member.summary: The Destination header, which specifies the destination container and object name for a Copy Object operation.
member.seealso: Copy Object (OpenStack Object Storage API v1 Reference)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.ObjectManifest
member.summary: The X-Object-Manifest header, which specifies the container and prefix for the segments of a large object.
member.seealso: Create Large Objects (OpenStack Object Storage API v1 Reference)

member.name: F:net.openstack.Providers.Rackspace.CloudFilesProvider.CdnPurgeEmail
member.summary: The X-Purge-Email header, which specifies the comma-separated list of email addresses to notify when a CDN purge request completes.

remarks.note: This header is a Rackspace-specific extension to the OpenStack Object Storage Service.

member.seealso: Purge CDN-Enabled Objects (Rackspace Cloud Files Developer Guide - API v1)

summary.para: The Cloud Servers Provider enables simple access go the Rackspace next generation Cloud Servers powered by OpenStack. The next generation service is a fast, reliable, and scalable cloud compute solution without the risk of proprietary lock-in. It provides the core features of the OpenStack Compute API v2 and also deploys certain extensions as permitted by the OpenStack Compute API contract. Some of these extensions are generally available through OpenStack while others implement Rackspace-specific features to meet customers expectations and for operational compatibility. The OpenStack Compute API and the Rackspace extensions are known collectively as API v2.

member.remarks: Following a resize operation, the original server is not immediately removed. After testing if the resulting server is operating successfully, a call should be made to to keep the resized server, or to to revert to the original server. If 24 hours pass and neither of these methods is called, the server will be automatically confirmed.

member.summary: Places a server in rescue mode.
member.remarks:
This operation is completed asynchronously. To wait for the server to enter rescue mode, call with the state .
The provider may limit the duration of rescue mode, after which the rescue image is destroyed and the server attempts to reboot. Rescue mode may be explicitly exited at any time by calling .
member.param: The server ID. This is obtained from ServerBase.Id.
The region in which to execute this action. If not specified, the user's default region will be used.
The cloud identity to use for this request. If not specified, the default identity for the current provider instance will be used.

The returned collection has two keys: and .

member.name: P:net.openstack.Core.Domain.Server.HostId
member.summary: Gets the host ID for the server.
member.remarks:
The compute provisioning algorithm has an anti-affinity property that attempts to spread customer VMs across hosts. Under certain situations, VMs from the same customer might be placed on the same host. The Host ID represents the host your server runs on and can be used to determine this scenario if it is relevant to your application.
is unique per account and is not globally unique.

member.name: P:net.openstack.Core.Domain.Server.Progress
member.summary: Gets the build completion progress, as a percentage. The value of this property is not defined by OpenStack, and may not be consistent across vendors.
member.value: A percentage from 0 to 100 (inclusive) representing the build completion progress.

member.name: T:net.openstack.Core.Domain.Role
member.summary: A personality that a user assumes when performing a specific set of operations. A role includes a set of right and privileges. A user assuming that role inherits those rights and privileges.
member.remarks: In OpenStack Identity Service, a token that is issued to a user includes the list of roles that user can assume. Services that are being called by that user determine how they interpret the set of roles a user has and to which operations or resources each role grants access.

member.name: P:net.openstack.Core.Domain.UserDetails.DefaultRegion
member.summary: Gets the default region for the user.
member.remarks:
Users can be assigned a default region so that, when there is a choice between multiple endpoints associated with a service in the user's catalog, the endpoint for the user's default region will be selected if it is available. The default region is only used when a region is not explicitly specified in the API call.
This property is a Rackspace-specific extension to the OpenStack Identity Service.
member.seealso: Sample Authentication Request and Response (Rackspace Cloud Identity Client Developer Guide - API v2.0)
